author: Peerzada Ashiq
text:
There is a constant trickle of visitors at this multi-storeyed but humble house in Kulgam district around 70 km south of Srinagar. A whole village has taken up the task of tending to the widow of 90-year-old Janki Nath, the lone Pandit survivor in the village, after his demise recently.

Residents of Malvan, the Naths were known for not fleeing the place at the peak of raging violence in 1990s and staying put with the Muslim brethren. The lone daughter of the couple was married off in Jammu and presently lives there.

“I used to take suggestions from him before taking any step in life,” said Gull Mohammad Alai, a local.

With no Hindu Pandits around, Muslims of the village took it on themselves to perform the final rites as per Hindu customs.

“He was like family. He deserved the cremation as per the customs,” said Ghulam Hassan, another neighbour.

Bed-ridden for five years, Nath, who was a retired employee of the Irrigation Department, breathed his last on Saturday morning. A local youth, Sajad Ahmad, used to nurse the ailing Pandit on a daily basis. When Nath died, except for his aging wife, there was no one else from the family around.

“I will never leave this place. This is my home and I will die here. I live in a family so there’s need not to worry about anything,” said the mourning wife.

“I don’t have to worry about food, clothes and help here. The whole Muslim village is only a shout away,” she said.
title: Kashmir village nurses lone Pandit survivor
